This will determine if setup need to run automatically after build ISO and auto login into the SSH server. If use 'no' means, it will not run setup and need to manually do that, when specifying no, the system will not execute --setup argument but instead it will execute this:

-- #!/bin/bash # TODO will make the name of the script dynamic. Do not use 'maxisetup' # This script will only shutdown the current server that has script in it cd /root || exit 1 chmod +x maxisetup touch maxisetup.log ./maxisetup --shutdown-server 2>&1 | tee maxisetup.log echo "" --

Added new function _log() to format log entries with timestamp and other information. This log entry uses _echo() function to style the text colour.
Example: _log red "Warning this is not good!" _log warning "Warning this is not good!" _log error "Warning this is not good!"
The above 3 statements are equal and they will output the following text with red color:
[maxisetup|14-06-2021 00:24:51]: Warning this is not good!
To log the output into a file use the third argument as the file name like this:
_log green "Warning this is not good!" "/tmp/log_file.txt"
or with variable:
_log green "Warning this is not good!" "${REPORT_FILE}"
All _echo and echo statements will be changed to _log statement (pending)
To ignore text color when using _log() function put the keyword 'default' as the default color. Example:
_log default "This is the default message without colour"

Upgraded _echo function to replace _log() function. The _log() function is now deprecated.
Features of _echo function:
This will display a Hello World text with a red colour: # _echo red "Hello World"
This will display a Hello World text with a default terminal colour: # _echo default "Hello World" - default color
We can even pass the long message without string quotation, the script can differentiate between the color and message argument (but it is recommended to quote long string): # _echo red Hello how are you?
If you need to write in the default log file then append --report option after message like this: # _echo green "well I am OK!" --report
If you need a manual file report path, then specify after --report argument like this (if the file does not exist, it will be created): # _echo white "I need to report!" --report /var/log/report.test
If you need to have timestamp on _echo for every report then enable this new variable:
# Enable log timestamp LOG_TIMESTAMP="yes"
When you enable LOG_TIMESTAMP="yes", you will get the _echo output with timestamp like this:
[maxisetup|16-06-2021 01:16:38]: ================================== [maxisetup|16-06-2021 01:16:38]: echo "" [maxisetup|16-06-2021 01:16:38]: Sleeping ... [maxisetup|16-06-2021 01:16:53]: ==================================

Big changes to how Directadmin API is implemented. Previous method was using temporary authentication file. Now we do not need that anymore. We just need to pass --sign-as option. For example to add an IP 1.1.1.1 with subnet 255.255.255.0 as a user arafatx, you could do the following
da_api_admin add-ip --sign-as arafatx --ip-address 1.1.1.1 --netmask 255.255.255.0
If you omit the option --sign-as, the default user would be the first owner of the system. You can also use --sign-as option to specify role of the first user instead of their usernames. For example, to add an IP for the first owner you could do the following:
1) maxinet --da-api add-ip --sign-as owner1 --ip-address 1.1.1.1 --netmask 255.255.255.0
the script will try to find out the first owner of the system's username and its password to use with API. In config file, this owner has the index of 1 (eg: C_DA_OWNER_USERNAME1).
These are the reserved roles that cannot be used as directadmin username:

Added --rebuild option to linode API. It is used to force recreate a record. For example if we want to create a domain we would do this:
linode_api_admin create-domain --domain server.com --domain-type master --domain-email test@server.com --domain-ttl 300 --rebuild
This above command will create a linode domain server.com. If the domain already in linode DNS, it will skip creation and this will leave some default DNS records unchanged. When you put an extra --rebuild option, it will delete the domain and re-add. So you will start from scratch adding new DNS record for this domain

New changes to directadmin authentication usage
Now we dont use the hard looping method. We use simple check obtained from directadmin user directories. Look at the example how powerful is this method:
Let say the current user is admin that was just being created by admin. So normally, this user has the default authentication stored in /usr/local/directadmin/scripts/setup.txt
Now, let's demonstrate how to enable DKIM for a domain:
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --domain test.com
Notice the above command did not have --sign-as parameter. Hence it will automatically search the default admin from config file that has username ${C_DA_OWNER_USERNAME1}. If this does not exist, it will try to find this user in setup.txt and use that to enable-domain-dkim. If still not found, the script will halt
Now, lets take a look another way how to use sign-as:
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --sign-as reseller1 --domain test.com
Notice the above reseller1 is a reserved role (the other reserved roles are admin1, owner1 and user1). The api will first convert the role to username, in this case it will obtain the username from the first reseller ${C_DA_RESELLER_USERNAME1}. If not found, the script will halt
Now, lets take a look another way how to use sign-as with username
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --sign-as maxi32 --domain test.com
The above command will use user maxi32 that is found from config file (this user can be reseller, owner, admin or normal user). If found it will use the default owner password to do sign-as. So the username would be admin|maxi32. This feature is introduced by directadmin to authenticate client without password.
Now finally let's take a look that we can also use manual authentication for the API like this
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --api-username maxi32 --api-password abc123 --domain test.com
If the username and password dont exist, it will halt the script ask to supply correct username and password before being used by API.

Big changes to how Directadmin API is implemented. Previous method was using temporary authentication file. Now we do not need that anymore. We just need to pass --sign-as option. For example to add an IP 1.1.1.1 with subnet 255.255.255.0 as a user arafatx, you could do the following
da_api_admin add-ip --sign-as arafatx --ip-address 1.1.1.1 --netmask 255.255.255.0
If you omit the option --sign-as, the default user would be the first owner of the system. You can also use --sign-as option to specify role of the first user instead of their usernames. For example, to add an IP for the first owner you could do the following:
1) maxinet --da-api add-ip --sign-as owner1 --ip-address 1.1.1.1 --netmask 255.255.255.0
the script will try to find out the first owner of the system's username and its password to use with API. In config file, this owner has the index of 1 (eg: C_DA_OWNER_USERNAME1).
These are the reserved roles that cannot be used as directadmin username:
owner1, admin1, reseller1, user1

Added --rebuild option to linode API. It is used to force recreate a record. For example if we want to create a domain we would do this:
linode_api_admin create-domain --domain server.com --domain-type master --domain-email test@server.com --domain-ttl 300 --rebuild
This above command will create a linode domain server.com. If the domain already in linode DNS, it will skip creation and this will leave some default DNS records unchanged. When you put an extra --rebuild option, it will delete the domain and re-add. So you will start from scratch adding new DNS record for this domain

New changes to directadmin authentication usage
Now we dont use the hard looping method. We use simple check obtained from directadmin user directories. Look at the example how powerful is this method:
Let say the current user is admin that was just being created by admin. So normally, this user has the default authentication stored in /usr/local/directadmin/scripts/setup.txt
Now, let's demonstrate how to enable DKIM for a domain:
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --domain test.com
Notice the above command did not have --sign-as parameter. Hence it will automatically search the default admin from config file that has username ${C_DA_OWNER_USERNAME1}. If this does not exist, it will try to find this user in setup.txt and use that to enable-domain-dkim. If still not found, the script will halt
Now, lets take a look another way how to use sign-as:
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --sign-as reseller1 --domain test.com
Notice the above reseller1 is a reserved role (the other reserved roles are admin1, owner1 and user1). The api will first convert the role to username, in this case it will obtain the username from the first reseller ${C_DA_RESELLER_USERNAME1}. If not found, the script will halt
Now, lets take a look another way how to use sign-as with username
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --sign-as maxi32 --domain test.com
The above command will use user maxi32 that is found from config file (this user can be reseller, owner, admin or normal user). If found it will use the default owner password to do sign-as. So the username would be admin|maxi32. This feature is introduced by directadmin to authenticate client without password.
Now finally let's take a look that we can also use manual authentication for the API like this
da_api_admin enable-domain-dkim --api-username maxi32 --api-password abc123 --domain test.com
If the username and password dont exist, it will halt the script ask to supply correct username and password before being used by API.
